BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As the precipitation becomes more intense the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent towards the evening.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 25 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1500 m. More recent wind slabs are covered with new snow and therefore difficult to recognise.
As the snowfall becomes more intense the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase. Towards the evening danger level 4 (high) will be reached above the tree line.
In particular from starting zones at higher altitudes and on steep slopes large dry avalanches are possible.
Backcountry touring calls for caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
In some places new snow is lying on a hard crust. The new snow will become increasingly prone to triggering.
As a consequence of snowfall and the southeasterly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form.
The meteorological conditions will cause a gradual rise in the danger of dry avalanches in the afternoon.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will increase. This applies in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As the precipitation becomes more intense the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent towards the evening.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 25 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1500 m. More recent wind slabs are covered with new snow and therefore difficult to recognise.
As the snowfall becomes more intense the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase. Towards the evening danger level 4 (high) will be reached above the tree line.
In particular from starting zones at higher altitudes and on steep slopes large dry avalanches are possible.
Backcountry touring calls for caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
In some places new snow is lying on a hard crust. The new snow will become increasingly prone to triggering.
As a consequence of snowfall and the southeasterly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form.
The meteorological conditions will cause a gradual rise in the danger of dry avalanches in the afternoon.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will increase. This applies in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gradual increase in avalanche danger as the precipitation becomes more intense.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 25 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1500 m. More recent wind slabs are covered with new snow and therefore difficult to recognise.
Not yet all starting zones have released the snow entirely. In particular in the regions with a lot of snow and above the tree line more large dry avalanches are possible.
As the snowfall becomes more intense the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase. Towards the evening danger level 4 (high) will be reached above the tree line.
The current avalanche situation calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In all altitude zones a lot of snow is already lying. As a consequence of snowfall and the southeasterly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form.
In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust.
The new snow will become increasingly prone to triggering. The meteorological conditions will cause a gradual rise in the danger of dry avalanches in the afternoon.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will increase. This applies in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gradual increase in avalanche danger as the precipitation becomes more intense.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 25 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1500 m. More recent wind slabs are covered with new snow and therefore difficult to recognise.
Not yet all starting zones have released the snow entirely. In particular in the regions with a lot of snow and above the tree line more large dry avalanches are possible.
As the snowfall becomes more intense the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase. Towards the evening danger level 4 (high) will be reached above the tree line.
The current avalanche situation calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In all altitude zones a lot of snow is already lying. As a consequence of snowfall and the southeasterly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form.
In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust.
The new snow will become increasingly prone to triggering. The meteorological conditions will cause a gradual rise in the danger of dry avalanches in the afternoon.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will increase. This applies in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of new snow and wind the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent towards the evening. In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation this applies especially.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1500 m. More recent wind slabs are covered with new snow and therefore difficult to recognise.
As a consequence of new snow and southeasterly wind, further wind slabs will form.
In particular in the regions exposed to precipitation and above the tree line more medium-sized to large dry avalanches are possible. They can occur in particular in starting zones where previous releases have taken place.
Above the tree line and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain the avalanche situation is dangerous. Experience and restraint are required.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
As a consequence of snowfall and the southeasterly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form.
In some places new snow is lying on a hard crust. The new snow will become increasingly prone to triggering.
Weak layers exist in the old snowpack.
The meteorological conditions will cause a gradual rise in the danger of dry avalanches in the afternoon.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will increase. This applies in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs in high Alpine regions. In particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation the wind slabs will increase in size additionally. Gliding avalanches can be released at any time of day or night.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh snow and the large wind slabs represent the main danger. As a consequence of the snowfall slab avalanches are possible, even large ones in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack will be unstable in particular on steep northeast, north and northwest facing slopes. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with the old snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and weakly bonded old snow require caution. Gliding snow requires caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a sometimes strong southwesterly wind, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs will form on Saturday. Caution is to be exercised in particular on steep shady slopes, as well as adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls in particular at elevated altitudes.
Weak layers in the upper part of the snowpack can be released by individual winter sport participants. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. Places where surface hoar has been covered with snow are especially unfavourable. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases. Careful route selection is recommended.
In addition a latent danger of gliding avalanches exists, in particular on sunny slopes below approximately 2400 m. These can in isolated cases reach quite a large size. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided as far as possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Friday. The wind will be strong at times over a wide area. Fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers at elevated altitudes. This applies above approximately 2400 m.
Faceted weak layers exist in the top section of the old snowpack on west, north and east facing slopes. This applies above approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area 25 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Sunday above approximately 1500 m. Significant increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and strong wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs of the last few days represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In all aspects large and, in isolated cases, very large avalanches are possible. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. In addition the new snow-covered wind slabs must be taken into account. The new snow and wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant, above approximately 1800 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of snowfall and the wind, snow drift accumulations formed. Weak layers exist in the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area intensive precipitation. As a consequence of new snow and wind from southerly directions, further wind slabs will form. In particular places where weaknesses exist in the old snowpack are especially precarious.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation and on steep slopes medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large loose snow avalanches are possible as a consequence of the new snow. The new snow and wind slabs of Wednesday can be released easily in all aspects above the tree line. Individual gliding avalanches can also occur. As a consequence of the rain, the likelihood of gliding avalanches and snow slides being released will increase on very steep slopes below approximately 1400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area new snow is lying on the soft surface of an old snowpack. The fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on northwest to north to northeast facing aspects above approximately 2500 m. The fresh wind slabs are to be assessed with care and prudence. In particular slopes adjacent to ridgelines are especially precarious.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area wind and new snow. Over a wide area 30 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1500 m. Gradual increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and weakly bonded old snow require caution. This applies above approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Weak layers in the upper part of the snowpack can be released by individual winter sport participants. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m, caution is to be exercised in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation on the Main Alpine Ridge. Places where surface hoar has been covered with snow are especially unfavourable. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases. Careful route selection is recommended.

As a consequence of new snow and a sometimes strong southwesterly wind, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs will form. Caution is to be exercised in particular on very steep shady slopes, as well as adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas above approximately 2200 m. The prevalence of such avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude.
In addition a latent danger of gliding avalanches exists, in particular on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m. These can in isolated cases reach medium size. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided as far as possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Up to 10 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall, especially in the Ultental, in the Texel Mountains and in the Stubai Alps. The new snow of the last few days is lying on surface hoar in particular on wind-protected shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. Fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers at elevated altitudes.

Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the old snowpack in particular on west, north and east facing slopes. This applies above approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Gradual increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and strong wind. Over a wide area 15 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Sunday.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind and new snow: The avalanche danger will increase during the day.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The new snow of Saturday will be deposited on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack.
As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong southeasterly wind, sometimes large wind slabs will form in the afternoon in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas as well as above approximately 2000 m.
The new snow and wind slabs can be released naturally. In addition in the afternoon an increasing number of medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large dry avalanches are possible. They can occur in particular in starting zones where previous releases have taken place.
Fresh wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence. As the snowfall becomes more intense the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase. They can be released by a single winter sport participant above approximately 2000 m. These places are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.
The current avalanche situation calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
30 to 60 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until Saturday above approximately 1500 m. The new snow of Saturday is bonding poorly with the old snowpack in some places in all aspects. Caution is to be exercised on wind-protected shady slopes. Towards its surface, the snowpack is unfavourably layered and its surface consists of surface hoar.
As a consequence of highly fluctuating temperatures and solar radiation a crust formed on the surface during the last few days, in particular on sunny slopes.
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
Wind and new snow:
The avalanche danger will already increase in the early morning.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind and new snow: The avalanche danger will increase during the day.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The new snow of Saturday will be deposited on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack.
As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong southeasterly wind, sometimes large wind slabs will form in the afternoon in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas as well as above approximately 2000 m.
The new snow and wind slabs can be released naturally. In addition in the afternoon an increasing number of medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large dry avalanches are possible. They can occur in particular in starting zones where previous releases have taken place.
Fresh wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence. As the snowfall becomes more intense the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase. They can be released by a single winter sport participant above approximately 2000 m. These places are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.
The current avalanche situation calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
30 to 60 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until Saturday above approximately 1500 m. The new snow of Saturday is bonding poorly with the old snowpack in some places in all aspects. Caution is to be exercised on wind-protected shady slopes. Towards its surface, the snowpack is unfavourably layered and its surface consists of surface hoar.
As a consequence of highly fluctuating temperatures and solar radiation a crust formed on the surface during the last few days, in particular on sunny slopes.
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
Wind and new snow:
The avalanche danger will already increase in the early morning.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be gradually wet all the way through.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be reduced. The surface of the snowpack is frozen, but not to a significant depth and will soften quickly. Individual, then as the precipitation becomes heavier more, and in some cases even medium-sized, gliding avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2000 m. As a consequence of mild temperatures and snowfall the snowpack can not consolidate.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs require caution. Gliding snow at intermediate altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a sometimes strong southwesterly wind, wind slabs will form in particular in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. These can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases in particular on shady slopes above approximately 2200 m. Mostly avalanches are medium-sized.

A latent danger of gliding avalanches exists, in particular on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m. These can reach medium size. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided as far as possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some snow will fall. The wind will be strong in some cases. Fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers at elevated altitudes. The old snowpack will be moist below approximately 2200 m.

Faceted weak layers exist in the top section of the old snowpack on west, north and east facing slopes. This applies above approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Gradual increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and strong wind. Over a wide area 10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Sunday.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The new snow of Saturday will be deposited on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack.
As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong southeasterly wind, wind slabs will form in the afternoon in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas as well as above approximately 2200 m. In the afternoon in some localities danger level 3 (considerable) will be reached.
The new snow and wind slabs can be released naturally. In addition in the afternoon in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas, small and medium-sized dry avalanches are possible.
Fresh wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence. In particular at intermediate and high altitudes the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase. They can be released by a single winter sport participant. These places are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.
The current avalanche situation calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
20 to 40 cm of snow will fall until Saturday above approximately 1500 m. The new snow of Saturday is bonding poorly with the old snowpack in some places. Caution is to be exercised on wind-protected shady slopes. Towards its surface, the snowpack is unfavourably layered and its surface consists of surface hoar.
As a consequence of solar radiation a crust formed on the surface during the last few days, in particular on sunny slopes.
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
Some new snow:
The avalanche danger will increase during the day.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The new snow of Saturday will be deposited on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack.
As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong southeasterly wind, wind slabs will form in the afternoon in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas as well as above approximately 2200 m. In the afternoon in some localities danger level 3 (considerable) will be reached.
The new snow and wind slabs can be released naturally. In addition in the afternoon in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas, small and medium-sized dry avalanches are possible.
Fresh wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence. In particular at intermediate and high altitudes the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase. They can be released by a single winter sport participant. These places are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.
The current avalanche situation calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
20 to 40 cm of snow will fall until Saturday above approximately 1500 m. The new snow of Saturday is bonding poorly with the old snowpack in some places. Caution is to be exercised on wind-protected shady slopes. Towards its surface, the snowpack is unfavourably layered and its surface consists of surface hoar.
As a consequence of solar radiation a crust formed on the surface during the last few days, in particular on sunny slopes.
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
Some new snow:
The avalanche danger will increase during the day.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs of Wednesday can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in all aspects above the tree line. Individual gliding avalanches can also occur. The wind slabs are easy to recognise and can be released by large loads in particular. The wind slabs of the last few days are to be evaluated with care and prudence in particular on northwest to north to northeast facing aspects above the tree line. These are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area new snow is lying on the soft surface of an old snowpack. The fresh wind slabs are to be assessed with care and prudence. In particular slopes adjacent to ridgelines are especially precarious.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on steep shady slopes at high altitude. In very isolated cases avalanches are medium-sized.

On steep slopes mostly small gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Up to 10 cm of snow will fall. The wind slabs are in isolated cases prone to triggering.

At low altitude no snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Gradual increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and strong wind. Over a wide area 10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Sunday.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on steep shady slopes at high altitude. Mostly avalanches are small but can be released easily even by a single winter sport participant. In very isolated cases avalanches are medium-sized.
On steep sunny slopes mostly small moist snow slides are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In some regions 10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Friday. As a consequence of the moderate to strong wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form on Saturday. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are in isolated cases prone to triggering. At low altitude hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area 25 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Sunday above approximately 1500 m. Significant increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and strong wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Wind slabs have formed in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls and generally at high altitudes. Avalanches are possible in isolated cases as before. In the relevant regions these are mostly small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The new snow of the last few days is lying on the quite favourable surface of an old snowpack above approximately 1900 m. In the last few days small wind slabs formed in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls as well as at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. Some fresh snow and the wind slabs will be deposited on a quite favourable old snowpack above approximately 1700 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet snow represents the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The weather conditions will give rise to increasing softening of the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The solar radiation will give rise from early morning to gradual softening of the snowpack. Little snow has fallen in some localities.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be gradually wet all the way through.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The surface of the snowpack is not frozen and will already be soft in the early morning.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2000 m. As a consequence of high temperatures and rain the snowpack could settle hardly at all.
